Hello America. So glad you can join us. Yes, this is a new edition of John Solomon reports,

feminist, overtly and openly liberal, but who has found much common ground with conservatives in
America the last several months. She is fighting and suing to keep biological males out of the
prison cells of females. In California, particularly, there's quite a racket. All you have to do is
say as you identify as a woman, and you can get into the female prison. There have been some horrific
sexual assaults and physical assaults and psychological torment going on in the California
female prison system. Because of this policy, Lauren Adams sued that. She has a lot to say about
Leah Thomas, a biological male, identifying as a female, competing in the NCAA female swimming
championship and winning. And a little bit to say about, believe it or not, Judge Jackson's
inability during last week's Supreme Court nomination hearing to be able to define what a woman is.
I think she took great umbrage to that Lauren Adams. We're going to ask her about that as well.
Great show today. We're going to take a quick commercial break. Get queued up. When we come
back, Lauren Adams, first up, legal director for the women's liberation front, followed by
my good friend, the great investigator, the great whistleblower champion, Jason Foster.
Wanna show. Hope you enjoy it.
You love on the IR radio app for free.

All right, folks. Welcome back to from the commercial break. So glad you rejoined us. We have a great
guest. She's been on his podcast before doing some really important work in the space of prisons.
And of course, as we among many examples of the continuing censorship is going on America,
it's a head scratcher joining me right now is Lauren Adams, legal director for the Women's
Liberation Front. Lauren, great to have you on the show today. Thank you for having me.
I want to start just to remind people because it's been a while since you're on the show,
what the Women's Liberation Front does and it's stances and what it's on particularly tried to do
in the state of California against the prison system. Yeah, so we are the largest national
feminist organization who is working on women's rights. Most of the real big hitters, women's
rights organizations don't actually fight for women's rights anymore. So there's other groups
that have had to step up and take over on that. In California, we are currently, we've sued the
state of California over their policy of putting male offenders into women's prisons. They passed
a bill that took effect last year, early last year, that allowed people to in the prison setting to
choose what sex they are treated as for the purposes of housing and for other purposes. And
there have been about 300 requests from the men's prison to transfer to the women's prison and
they've already transferred several dozen, which has had a number of awful effects. And it's a,
it's inhumane and it's a violation of their rights. So we are seeking to rectify that.
Yeah. And when you say negative effects, right, there, there have been sexual assaults in the
prison by some of these biological males and biological females, correct? Yeah, sexual assault,
physical assault, sexual harassment, intimidation, threats, exhibitionism, voyeurism. I mean,
there's no privacy in there. So it's really easy to kind of get peeped on and it's almost impossible
to prove that someone's doing it intentionally, but you have them almost all of these men are,
you know, not almost none of them have had surgery of any kind or anything. So these are just
regular intact men. Yep. They just say they identify as a woman, but they're clear biological males.
The law only requires that they say that they identify as women, actually, they just have to
identify as not men. So they can identify as, I think the statute says they can be non-binary,
gender fluid, gender queer, and they give a bunch of other examples. Yeah. I mean, all you
literally have, you don't have to say you identify as a woman, you don't have to take hormones.
The prisons are not allowed to take anatomy into account when making housing decisions. So
essentially, and since there's no women transferring to the men's prison, we essentially now have
men's prison and co-ed prisons, basically. Wow. Unreal. That's a remarkable moment. And I want
to clarify, you're not, you're not discriminating. You don't have any problem with a person's choice
to identify. What you're worried about is the safety and security issues and psychological
things that this is causing for the women in the prison, correct? Absolutely. And there's two
really, I guess, important things to remember. And one is that our arguments are really based
on sex. So we are seeking to have men, male people removed from the women's prison. There are a lot
of biological females in the women's prison who identify as men or identify as non-binary,
and we want them to stay put where it's safe. So it's really, it's not that we don't like
certain people or want them to generally be away from women. It's that we just think that
prisons like domestic violence shelters, like sports, like everything else should be separated by sex
when it makes sense to, which is usually. So I think that's important to remember. The other thing that
that's really important to know, and as far as I know, this is not applicable to the general
population, but specifically in the prison context, males who identify as transgender are
dramatically more likely to be sex offenders, according to state and federal data. So,
in the federal system, 48% of men who self-identify as transgender are sex offenders.
That's data from the Bureau of Prisons, and in California, it's 38%. And a third of those who
have requested transfers are sex offenders, and that's compared to only like 14% of the regular
male population and an unnegligible portion of the female population. So it's statistically
significant. This is a significant data point. Oh, yeah. And we've gotten public records requests
on the crimes committed by the men. So these are men who are already in the women's facilities.
And it's horrific. There's forcible rape. There's vicious sex crimes and
arson kidnapping, murder, things like that. There's one there for raping and torturing two women.
There's one who's there for killing two infants, and the mother of those infants is in there with
him. It's as awful as you can imagine it being. Yeah. Yeah. Or worse. Just extraordinary.
Wow. I mean, this is such an important issue now. Let me see if I got this right. This may,
I almost have a hard time saying that this was said, but were you actually accused of committing
genocide by word simply by trying to defend the women in these prisons? Oh, yeah. And that lovely
creature who wrote that in that editorial by name saying I was said a lot of stuff, but
genocide by word caught my particular attention. Yes, it would catch mine too. Yeah. So the man
who wrote that his name is Michael Contreras Hernandez. He is serving a life sentence for multiple
murders. He killed a man in the men's prison before transferring to the women's prison.
And his behavior is so erratic that the women who have shared cells with him have
taken turns staying awake at night because he stays awake or at times has, I think it's drug
induced is the speculation from the women who are spending time around him that he's a very
dangerous person. And you know, he's an intact male. He's very, he's very scary and intimidating.
And a history in a history of bad context. Yes. That's a guy. Excusing me of genocide by word.
The literal murderer. Unreal. Unreal. Unreal. You have recently were kicked off a fundraising
platform. We were trying to raise women to help raise money to help these women in the prison.
Talk a little bit about what happens there and what was your sin? What was your violation?
They didn't say. They never do. So, yeah, it was so we used give butter because, you know,
we felt that it was less likely to deplatform us and go fund me. We've seen how people have
been traded on there and we wanted to use some platform that in the past has been less, you know,
inclined to censor. So, yes, all they said they did, they did not give us a reason. We've appealed.
And they just said, it was the most innocuous thing too. We were just a national fundraiser.
It was trying to get some the state by state thing you could give to the money that your,
your region. So, it gives to the Midwest. If you're in the Midwest and it was very much not,
not the fundraiser you'd expect to get canceled, I guess.
Yeah, no. We're a 501c3 public charity. I mean, it is unreal. Not that anyone should be censored,
but yeah. But I mean, you already approved. And when people understand this part of the work,
I mean, this is just about a safety issue. This is about making sure that women in prisons don't
get victimized in some form. And it's just, to me, it's mind-boggling to see how far we've come.
Let me walk you through some of the recent headlines and get your take on where you stand.
I mean, you're very liberal, right? You're politically liberal.
And so, yeah. And when you see, let's take on Leah Thomas. She's competing as a biological male
against women in the NCA Championship, taking most of the awards. You see the,
I, some of the pictures where you see the other swimmers, you know, would have been first,
if it weren't for Leah Thomas being in the lineup, the disappointment, the frustration.
How do you reconcile? What goes to your mind when you see that?
That it's a natural and predictable consequence of these policies that we can expect to see more of
as time goes on. And I think that, obviously, it's unconscionable and to take away those opportunities
for women to compete. And if you look at the, people will say, oh, it's a small number of people,
but look how many women were displaced by his participation. How many were knocked off the team
or the chance to compete, the chance to go to the next level and things like that. It's,
it's completely absurd. And, you know, he's in the locker room naked. Apparently,
they have trouble getting him to cover up. It's completely predictable and foreseeable.
Yeah. So, you know, you're a feminist, but you, you don't support biological males
competing against females, right? No, not when it's other, not for female-only teams. Absolutely,
not. I mean, obviously, there's colored teams that are good. Right, of course. Yeah, I just didn't
say that well, but on an all female sport, right? Yeah, I, in situations, whether it's sports or
otherwise, where it is permissible and ethical to exclude males, right, locker rooms, etc.
Sports, right? I don't believe that there should be exceptions for certain kinds of males.
Yeah, it's a pretty straightforward answer. And let me take you to an answer that wasn't so
straightforward just a few days ago. Obviously, Judge Kintangi, Brown Jackson going through her
confirmation. And I understand the politics of this Republicans are trying to create moments,
but they asked her, could she define a woman in the first two or three times? She couldn't
as a feminist, what did that feel like? Seeing another woman who couldn't define what a woman was?
It's very disappointing. It's very disappointing to hear that. And also, again, predictable,
because you know that any candidate or any nominee who's put forth by this president is
going to have already been vetted for their opinion on this subject. It's absurd.
Some of the stuff you can only laugh at too, I've seen memes go around where you have a cop
hold someone over and said, do you know how fast you were going? And he says, sir, I'm not a physicist.
But yeah, it's really- That's kind of funny actually. Yeah.
There's a lot of good ones. But yes, it's very disappointing. And I really, really do hope that
it was just one of those moments, like you said, and not something that is indicative of how
she would rule on the bench. Because I do think she's- My organization doesn't have a position
on her. I do personally think she would be overall a good justice. And I think that this is really
unfortunate. And I hope it's not representative of how she actually feels, even though it's what
she needs to say, right? Like, sir. It seems as though this cancel culture has made even very smart,
bright people hesitant to answer questions that used to be common sense. You could answer them
without consequence. And now people are afraid to be caught in the cancel culture and censorship
world. And, you know, there's no doubt that Judge Jackson is a very bright person, well-educated,
well-spoken, couldn't find the courage to answer that question, which by the way is not very hard
to answer. But just- I think it's more not only a statement about her, it's probably more a statement
about this moment in our country where we can't even have common sense conversation. Rachel Levine,
the high-ranking HHS official who is also an admiral, recently was named by USA to be as one of its
women of the year. You're thought about a biological male, obviously transgender,
identifying, getting a woman of the year award. I think it's a travesty. You're really doing the
greatest tips of all my favorite people right now. Sorry about that. Well, these are the moments.
I mean, this is what people really are talking about, you know. I was in our Twitter because you
throw it off on there. But in real, in homes, we're all struggling with this.
Of course. And Rachel Levine is truly an absurd individual who's not fit for the office. I,
you know, if for no other reason than his views on child transitioning, that Senator Paul asked about
during the confirmation hearing last year. As like the secretary, or what was it, the secretary of
health, I can't remember. Was it Pennsylvania? I'm trying to think about it. Yeah, that's right.
Made terrible decisions and said terrible things about, you know, children's ability to consent to
life-altering procedures, sterilizing procedures without their parents' consent or,
you know, kids in the foster system talking about how they should be fast-tracked. So I think that
this person, I think it's terrible. Just again, someone who's knocked off the list, right? There's
a woman who's not being honored because of that. And they have to. You know that if they didn't
include someone like that, they have complaints there would be that the list wasn't like inclusive
enough. Yeah, it's really remarkable. Are we in this cycle forever or is there a moment where people
realize, let's stop the world for a second. I want to get off and have a common sense conversation.
Do we get to a point in the future where we can have an honest conversation that, you know,
we don't all agree with what the elitist is saying. We don't agree with these policies. We want our
daughters to compete against daughters in sports. Again, never discriminating. This doesn't have to
go the other way and say, oh, we're going to discriminate, make fun of people. That's going
backwards. But certainly there's a legitimate debate in America. And there's a small group of
people that are trying to prevent that debate from occurring. Can it be overcome?
I think so. And I think it will be, although I don't know the timeline, but I think it's really
helpful to think of what we're going through right now as a moral panic. And I'm not trying to say
this as like to be overdramatic. But I think of like the Salem witch trials and what people got
caught up in or the red scare, you know, or just things like that where there's just this
escalating, having to have the right opinions and the consequences of it. They just want to
destroy people. It's unsustainable just in human group psychology. I really think so. I just am
looking for the end of it. I say that people talking and people getting together and sharing
ideas is really valuable. Like you said, just regular people. I love the work that I do with
our nonpartisan partners. We work all across the spectrum left to right at Wolf. And I just
learned so much and it's made me a much better person, I think, just being exposed to more ideas
and more kinds of people getting along. And I think we're going to just see more that people
are going to start to opt out of some of the online stuff. I think you're right. In fact,
I have a theory and a lot of times conservatives say, oh, I'm being shadow banned on Twitter. I'm
not sure we're being shadow banned. I think that many people have just dropped off the platform
and didn't cancel their accounts. I think there's a moment where people are just saying, oh my god,
stop this. I'm not going to go on that for this. And it's funny how sometimes free market forces
end up sorting these things out, which is all right, you guys want to have that? You can be that,
but I'm not I'm not joining your product anymore. I think that's going to be I think it's not going
to be a boycott. It's just going to be people like, yeah, I'm moving on to something else. It
doesn't match my values. You have so much that your group does. And obviously,
the prison lawsuit is very important. You strongly support women in so many different ways.
There's a lot of conservative listeners on this podcast. They may not agree with all of the
philosophies, but the idea that women should be protected, that young girls should be protected,
is something we all universally share. What are some of the other things that you're doing at WLF?
Yeah, so we we have our core issue areas include reproductive autonomy, which is broader than
for us, just abortion rights. I know it's definitely something in the audience, probably.
But you look at it as the right to have children too. So the right against sterilization and that
goes into some of the child transitioning things and the things that we do to harm young people.
And sterilization, you look at what's going on in China, surrogacy, commercial surrogacy,
and other commercial sexual and reproductive exploitation, pornography and prostitution.
All of these things go hand in hand. The people who are promoting things like putting men and
women's prisons, they're also promoting legalizing other ways that women are objectified and exploited
for profit. I mean, porn is like a many, many billion dollar industry. And it is,
it is for me. People make fun of like some states have declared it a public health crisis and people
make fun of that. I almost think that's understating it. What it does to the people who view it or
participate in it is just very harmful. So we work against that a lot. And then for LGBT rights,
so for the rights of lesbian and bisexual women, which again is much more expansive than things
like marriage or adoption rights, it really goes into political autonomy and the right to self
definition. And we have found a lot of common ground with our conservative partners on those
issues of, you know, people need to be able to decide who they're associating with and what they
can say about themselves and about groups that they're a part of. And right now you have lesbians
who get kicked off Twitter for saying that, you know, lesbians don't have male parts.
It's unreal. And they definitely, they're not getting their bands overturned.
You know, it's, yeah, no, it's amazing. Kind of what we do at Wolf. I know you also,
you know, I want to ask about this, but sex trafficking seems to be on the rise in a very
significant way. Many of the law enforcement officers I'm talking to are raising really serious
concerns about it. How bad is the problem in America's clearly ground zero for where we're one
of the largest repositories of sex trafficking rings? How bad a situation do we have in this
country right now? And what can we do to not only support the victims that have been rescued,
but also to try to stop the scourge? It is really bad. And I think some of it just being,
we have such a decentralized legal system. We got 50 states and then there's federal and it can be
really hard to stop what is a very ever moving process of moving people around.
I do think the best way to probably on a larger level support this is to fight against the
legalization of prostitution. There's a lot of really well-intentioned people who want to
say, okay, the best way to really get help to victims is to make sure that it's not,
you know, criminalized and then people can, but we see in other places that have legalized it
where it all it does is end up increasing demand and when you increase demand, then you need
people to increase supply. So they bring in, that's where you get more trafficking to that
area from other areas. And it just, as soon as you have the government saying, this is okay to do,
it's legal to do, then it kind of gives some moral permission to some people too. So I think
really resisting that urge to try and do that, we support the equality model, which is also
called the Nordic model, which decriminalizes the selling effects, but not the buying effects.
So it means that women and children who are prostituted, who are exploited,
are not charged with crimes. They're treated as victims, but that those who buy sex and those
who traffic and the events and all of that, that they are still charged. Yeah, so important. It is,
you're doing a lot of important work and it's shameful to think that the very important work you're
doing is being thwarted in some way by this insane censorship moment that is going on.
If people want to get involved or do something, how can they get involved with Wolf?
Well, you can follow us on social media. You can go to our website at women's liberationfront.org
and sign up for our email list. We often have calls to action that are state-specific
and opportunities to testify and we have resources for people who might want to get involved in
their own state and just find out what's going on and learn the latest things. But we're not going
to let ourselves be the platform. We'll just keep finding new platforms. We're not going to be quiet.
That's it. Yeah, don't stop. Eventually you're going to beat them. There's no doubt about it.
That's what we've learned in the censorship game somewhere soon. There's a platform that's
actually going to respect free speech and there are many now. They're coming up all over the place.
Lauren, it's always a pleasure to talk to you. I know you're fighting some very important
words. A lot of people don't want to think about these issues. They don't want to know that there
are men sleeping in, biological men sleeping in women's prison cells and assaulting women's
and you make us enforce us to think about it so that we can solve the problem and we're really
grateful for that work. Thank you. Thank you so much for having me on. This is great. A lot of fun.
All right, folks. We're going to take a quick commercial break. We'll be right back after this
commercial message.

Tonight, we are breaking some news of our own right here on this show. A major whistleblower
investigation has exposed new ethics problems inside the Veterans Affairs Department. Joining us
right now to tell us why this news is important is Jason Foster, the founder and president of the
very important whistleblower group called Empower Oversight. Jason, welcome to the show.
Hi, thanks for having me. Our pleasure. Okay, so for our audience who hasn't had a chance to go
to JustTheNews.com and read this story, give everybody just kind of an overview of the allegations,
the investigation and what the inspector general ultimately found. Sure, so early last year,
some whistleblowers went to Senator Grassley's office, my former employer, and they disclosed to
him some conflicts of interest that were going on at the Veterans Affairs Administration. So,
basically, the story is a senior official there who's in charge of GI Bill benefits,
had was married to someone who was, had a contract relationship working for an outside left-wing
organization that often has business before her. They're often advocating before this official,
and they were often seeking contracts and MOUs and access to data that they could use to raise money.
And so it presented what was a pretty obvious conflict of interest, a government official
whose spouse is involved in business that they're doing, making official decisions on that's not
appropriate, and it should be disclosed, and there should be steps taken to mitigate that
conflict of interest. So, Senator Grassley wrote to the VA and asked about this and a whole host of
related issues, and the inspector general opened an investigation late last year,
and they just finished their, or early last year, and they just finished their report and put it out
yesterday, which substantiated most of what the whistleblowers had told Senator Grassley's office,
which was that indeed this senior VA official who was in charge of GI Bill benefits was making
decisions on matters that were related to her husband's employer and her husband's clients.
And it took much longer than it should have to get to that truth, but it's finally now out in the
basic, the basic facts are pretty clear in the IG report, and it's a pretty egregious conflict
of interest. We at Empower Oversight had issued FOIA requests, Freedom of Information Act requests
to the VA last year, trying to get to find out why they were ignoring Senator Grassley's letters,
because he had sent two or three letters on this issue and had never gotten a response.
One of the things that we learned was we got a document through the Freedom of Information
Act that showed that the agency had actually gathered all the answers to Senator Grassley's
letter, but then they didn't send them, and the copy that they provided to us actually redacted
all of those answers. So we have appeals going on with the VA, and we're going to continue pushing
for more transparency. But essentially, the story is, this VA official did have this conflict of
interest. It wasn't properly disclosed. It wasn't properly dealt with. Her supervisors knew about
it. And now, as is typically the case in these matters, and John will be familiar with this
pattern, she resigned in the middle of the IG investigation. In fact, refused to cooperate with
the IG. That's one of the findings in the report is that she didn't fully cooperate as she was
required to do as a VA employee, and actually resigned rather than complete a second interview
with the IG about all these issues. Just amazing. Jason, you've been in this town a long time. You
are alongside Senator Grassley for some of the epic whistleblower cases of the last quarter century.
But there seems to be this extraordinary drop in concern about ethics. And when I say that, I mean,
listen, we know Hunter Biden had no problem jumping on Air Force II, going to Beijing,
cutting up a business deal with his dad on his side, or taking on the barisement thing while his
dad was in charge of Ukraine policy. But in Congress, we see spouses that are cashing in on their
congressional members, fame or policy positions. Have we gotten so far from the Watergate era,
the reforms of the Watergate era, that Washington just yawns about these very important requirements
that elected officials and bureaucratic officials are supposed to find?
Well, yes, a lot of the time, part of the problem, though, is, you know, it sort of depends on who's
who's ox is being bored. Right. Sometimes there, sometimes there seems to be a very aggressive
pursuit of ethics questions, you know, which is usually, you know, too often politically motivated.
Right. In, you know, in this case, there, there isn't a political motivation behind it. You know,
the whistleblowers, you know, who brought these issues to Senator Grassley, you know, they don't
have a political view that's that's contrary to the, you know, the current administration or the
